question: Hey, Renise.
answer: Hey.

question: So what's up?
answer: Eh.

question: Great. Great. So listen, uh, I was wondering if maybe you wanted to go to the prom you know, with me.
answer: See, the thing is, I heard a rumor that this guy I like was gonna ask me.

question: Uh-huh.
answer: Yeah, so...I'm gonna wait and see what happens there...But that sounds great, yeah.

question: Okay. So is that a yes or a no?
answer: I think I was very clear, Ted. If everything else falls apart, maybe.

question: Why don't you be a gentleman and ask Rosey?
answer: Who?

question: Rosey Palm, your girlfriend. God knows you spend enough fucking time with her.
answer: Yeah, and who are you gonna take, your own palm?

question: Some guy named Woogie.
answer: Who?

question: Big guy--goes to Barrington high school.
answer: Woogie from Borrington high? Sounds like a loser.

question: So who you taking to the prom?
answer: Huh?

question: The prom--you going?
answer: Oh, I don't know. I think proms are pretty dumb.

question: 'Cause I thought maybe you and I could go if you weren't already taking someone.
answer: I mean dumb in the sense that they only happen once a year.

question: All right, kid, that's it, I'm coming in.
answer: I wish.

question: You got what stuck?
answer: It.

question: It? Oh it. All right, these things happen, let me have a look. It's not the end of the world. OH FOR THE LOVE OF GOD!
answer: Shhhhhh! What?! No please, sir--

question: Teddy, hon, are you okay? OH HEAVENS TO PETE!
answer: Would you shhh! Mary's gonna hear us.

question: Just relax, dear. Now, um...what exactly are we looking at here?
answer: What do you mean?

question: You betcha! ...Anyway, school ended a few days later and that July her father got transferred to Florida. Anyway, it's not something you exactly forget about, but I guess I must've blocked it out of my head. Then about a week ago I'm driving on the highway and I got to thinking about Mary and suddenly I couldn't breathe...I couldn't keep up with the flow of traffic anymore I felt like I was going to die. I pulled into a rest area, parked the car, and just started shaking. Huh? What are you saying?
answer: Gay? He said you were gay?

question: He implied it.
answer: Well you're a writer, and a lot of writers are gay. Look at Truman Capote.

question: Yeah, but he was successful.
answer: Let me ask you this

question: Come on, that wouldn't make me gay.
answer: I'm going to fix you up with my new assistant.

question: What's he like?
answer: You're leaving it out. Finish your swing. You're going to like this one--she's half Asian, half American.

question: Good-looking?
answer: I just told you, she's half Asian. half American. They're all good looking. You could mate Don Rickles and Yoko Ono and they're going to have a gorgeous kid. It's a foolproof combo.

question: What's the point? Let's face it, Dom, I'm in a slump.
answer: Loser? You?

question: Oh, so I'm lucky because my brother got killed in an explosion?
answer: I never said that. I'm saying your lucky those kids found his kidneys. Besides, your brother Jimmy never gave a shit about you.

question: I gotta take this, it might be my boss. Ted here. Yep.
answer: Thanks, baby.

question: See, that's what I want. I don't need these bimbettes you got me chasing. I want what you have. A family....Someone to...you know...love.
answer: Each day is better than the next. Have you ever been, you know...in love with someone?

question: Nah.
answer: Never?

question: Well once. Mary.
answer: Mary again.

question: Look, I admit it was brief, but it was definitely love. Crushes don't last twelve years.
answer: Whatever happened to Mary?

question: I told you, her family moved to Miami.
answer: I mean since then.

question: I don't know.
answer: Well why don't you look her up?

question: Yeah, right.
answer: Why not?

question: Because I guarantee she's married and has a couple kids. Girls like Mary don't stay single.
answer: What if you're wrong? You just said she's the only girl you ever loved, what have you got to lose by calling her?

question: I did try calling her. A few years ago. She wasn't listed.
answer: So that was it? One bump in the road and you gave up?

question: I also called Unsolved Mysteries.
answer: You're kidding? What did they say?

question: They told me they don't help out stalkers. Look, maybe they're right, it's been a long time.
answer: I got it--you hire a private eye, fly him out there, he follows her around a couple days, she'll never know a thing.

question: No. No fucking way. That's too creepy.
answer: Wait a second. There's a guy named Healy in my office who might be able to help you out. He's a claims investigator and he goes to Miami every couple weeks.

question: I don't know about this, Dom.
answer: Relax, this guy owes me a big one. A couple years ago he got in a jam up in the Boston office; some bullshit about padding his resume--like we haven't all done that. Anyway, they were going to let him go but his mother wrote a tear-jerker letter that ended up on my desk.

question: His mother?
answer: Yeah, I guess he still lives with her. Seemed like a sweet lady--got diabetes or something--so I went out on a limb and got him transferred down to Providence.

question: And you think he could find out her number for me?
answer: He'll do better than that. I'll send him down to Miami on business, you throw him a couple bucks on the side, and he'll track her down.

question: So, Dom tells me you're looking for some lady-friend you knew in high school.
answer: Uh-huh.

question: Any idea where I might start looking?
answer: She moved to Miami Beach twelve years ago. I checked directory assistance down there and she's not listed. She might've moved ten times since then.

question: All you want is a phone number?
answer: Well, I know you're busy

question: Don't play games with me, Ted.
answer: I don't know, maybe you could poke around for a half day and see if she has five kids and a Labrador.

question: I don't buy it.
answer: You don't buy what?

question: Ted, I'm the kind of guy who shoots from the hip. Now I want you to level with me
answer: No.

question: She's blackmailing you, right?
answer: No.

question: You want her dead, don't you?
answer: You can't be serious.

question: Do you really expect me to believe this is a straight stalker case?
answer: I'm not a stalker ! She's a friend of mine.

question: Sure she is. That's why she got an unlisted number and you haven't heard squat from her in a dozen years. Oh you're good, Ted. You're a real piece of work.
answer: Look, let's forget it. Let's forget the whole thing.

question: I get one hundred a day plus expenses.
answer: You get fifty a day, period. It's a business trip, they'll pay for your expenses.

question: Okay, Ted, I'll do it. But if this chick turns up with a toe tag, I'm rolling over on you.
answer: Healy you dog!

question: Fucking Sully! Look at you!
answer: You hot shit. Ya look fuckin' pisser. Here's the info you asked for.

question: Thanks.
answer: You should thank me--that girl was not easy to find. What'd she scam you out of-some insurance dough?

question: Nah, some guy threw me a few bucks to track down his high school girlfriend.
answer: Stalker, huh?

question: Big time. Very nice.
answer: I'm doing okay. I gotta get ready for work.

question: Okay? With this pad, the killer wheels? Looks like you really cleaned up your act.
answer: What can I tell you? It's a healthier lifestyle down here, and it's easier to succeed when your head's clear. Those guys I worked with back in Boston, they were a bad influence.

question: Fuckin' animals. Hey, what do you say we go grab a couple drinks.
answer: Not for me, buddy. I don't drink anymore.

question: Yeah, and you don't drink any less, right?
answer: Take it easy, that's Bill.

question: Tell Bill to get the fuck off!
answer: Relax, he just ate.

question: What are you talking about? You were never an alky, you were a cokehead.
answer: Yeah, well when you quit blow, you gotta quit the booze, too.

question: Is that right? Well good for you, Sull, I'm proud of you.
answer: Healy, what I just tell you?

question: This is a light beer. You can't have a light beer?
answer: No I can't.

question: Sully, it's one fuckin' beer for Christ sakes. Ooh, the big bad beer's gonna get ya.
answer: Am I?

question: Bet your ass you are. Now I don't want to hear anymore of your happy horseshit. You gotta learn how to bend a little or believe me...you're gonna break.
answer: Jesus, you know what? This shit doesn't even taste good to me anymore.

question: Have you been up all night again?
answer: Bet your ass I have. It's an important job, Neighborhood Watch is.

question: Neighborhood Watch? Is that what you call listening in on stranger's phone conversations?
answer: These ain't strangers, they're neighbors. This only picks up signals in a half-mile radius.

question: Meaning?
answer: Meaning these are the people you live amongst, you got a right to know if they're creeps. For instance, did you know there's a guy down the hall cheating on his wife?

question: You picked that up on the scanner. We gotta move.
answer: I confirmed it on the scanner. I knew something was up because Puffy used to bark like hell whenever he saw him and you know Puffy only barks at bad people.

question: Magda, Puffy barks at everybody.
answer: That's because there's a lot of bad people out there. Hey, Puffy tried to warn you about that Steve guy you was seeing--he was a fucking asswipe--but you had to find out for yourself, didn't you?

question: But here's the rub. The guy I'm talking about has got to be self-employed.
answer: You mean, like an architect or something?

question: Architect, yeah. No, it's not the money. Creative, yeah, that's good, but it's the freedom I'm talking about. See, this guy has to have a job he could do anywhere. That way we could just up and leave at the drop of a hat.
answer: And where would you and your beer-bellied architect be leaving to?

question: I don't know. The Super Bowl, New Orleans Jazz Festival...maybe a couple months in Nepal.
answer: Yeah, and you'd probably dump the poor guy halfway to Katmandu.

question: What's that supposed to mean?
answer: It means you're too hard on guys.

question: No I'm not.
answer: Oh come off it, Mare. What about what's-his-name...Steverino? You could've at least passed the baton on that one.

question: Yeah, Steve. Steve was all right for awhile.
answer: All right for awhile? The guy's good-looking, rich, witty. He was a god.

question: Hello...? Sully...? Sully, that you?
answer: Who the fuck is it to you?

question: Sully, it's Healy. What's going on over there?
answer: Fuckin' Patrick Healy, you think your shit don't stink. Well I got news for you--you're goddamn right it don't! How the hell are ya?!

question: Uh, I'm fine. Just wanted to let you know I'll have your car back in a couple hours, I'm still staking out this girl's apartment.
answer: You found my car?!

question: Fucking Barney...he never learns... Here we go, Teddo. Here comes the money shot. I've got some very, very good news for you, my friend.
answer: Really? Very, very?

question: I think your life's about to change.
answer: So you found Mary?

question: Right there in Liberty City. And you were right, she's really something.
answer: So she hasn't changed?

question: That I couldn't. say. Let me ask you something
answer: No, not at all.

question: Well she must've packed on a few pounds over the years.
answer: Mary's a little chubby, huh?

question: I'd say about a deuce, deuce and a half. Not bad.
answer: So she's married?

question: Nope. Never been.
answer: Huh?

question: Four kids, three different guys.
answer: Three different guys?

question: Well I'm guessing. There's a black kid, two whites, and a midget.
answer: Oh my.

question: Hyperactive little fuckers, too. Tough to keep up with in a wheelchair, I bet.
answer: She's in a wheelchair?!

question: Don't look so shocked, it's been a long time. I bet you've changed a lot over the last twelve years, haven't you?
answer: It's just that...Mary. I wouldn't have thought...

question: Anyway, the good news is I have all the information you need. Got it from her bookie--nice guy. You should definitely call her, Ted. I mean she's a real sparkplug, that one. She seems determined to get those rugrats off welfare and with your help I'll bet she does it.
answer: Thanks, Healy. Good work.

question: Ted? Don't you want the name of the housing project?
answer: Uh, that's okay.

question: You sure, big guy? I'll bet she'd love to hear from you before her mastectomy!
answer: What are you doing?

question: Oh, uh, I resigned.
answer: Miami?

question: Yeah, this insurance business is too slow for me. I'm going to go down and try my hand at jai alai.
answer: Jai alai?

question: Yeah, I don't know why but I always felt at home in the fronton.
answer: Look, uh, I've been thinking about everything you told me.

question: Good good.
answer: Well I think you're right, I should look her up.

question: Rollerpig? Are you nuts?
answer: But you said she was a sparkplug...?

question: I said buttplug. She's heinous.
answer: All the same, I still want to call her. I know it sounds crazy--Mary sure has a lot of troubles in her life--but, I don't know, maybe I can help her out. The poor thing's had it tough--she's in a wheelchair for Godsakes.

question: It's a goddamn bunion. It'll heal.
answer: Oh. I thought That's not it anyway. I know this doesn't make any sense to you, but I just can't turn it off that fast. I still feel something for her.

question: Okay, tell you what
answer: Japan? What's she doing in Japan?

question: You've heard of mail-order brides? Well they go that way, too.
answer: Mary's a mail-order bride?

question: Fetched a pretty penny, too. Don't forget, it's the Sumo culture, they pay by the pound there. Sort of like tuna.
answer: That's it, I'm making an oath. I'll never procrastinate about anything again. Life is too fucking short.

question: That's it, I'm making an oath. I'll never procrastinate about anything again. Life is too fucking short.
answer: Hey, look on the bright side--

question: What's that, Dom? What's the bright side?
answer: Well...at least now you know.

question: I think it was better when I didn't. It was kind of inspiring to know there was someone so pure in the world. What's so funny?
answer: I'm sorry, it's just that you're taking this all wrong, pal. Don't you see? You're liberated. I feel liberated. I mean here you've been in therapy thinking you blew it with the greatest girl ever, and it turns out that getting your dick stuck in your zipper was the best thing that ever happened to you!

question: Wait a second, I never told you that.
answer: Christ, Ted, I was only four towns away.

question: Maybe you're right. I should look on the bright side. I mean, I've still got my health... I'm out of here. I've got to get up at six a.m. to move my boss's brother into his apartment.
answer: What? On your day off? Do you even know the guy?

question: Never met him.
answer: Jesus, Ted, you've got to finish that damn novel so you can quit that stupid magazine.

question: Hit a house! Bite bite! Haven't swung the wrenches in a while.
answer: Yeah, don't talk in someone's backswing.

question: Thanks.
answer: No thanks.

question: Oh cripes. Do you have change for a dollar? All I have is these stupid Nepalese coins.
answer: Nepal? Have you been?

question: Not in months. I don't even know why I bought the damn place.
answer: You own a home there?

question: Well...it's just a condo really. Right outside Katmandu.
answer: Wow. That's a place I've always wanted to go. Is it true the mountains are so tall you can't see the tops?

question: Not 'til you get about three hundred yards from the summit. That's been my experience anyway.
answer: Thanks. Well, it was nice meeting you, again.

question: Same here again.
answer: By the way, what's your name?

question: Pat Healy.
answer: Don't you want to know my name?

question: I already know it, Mary.
answer: How'd you know that?

question: It's right there on your golf bag.
answer: What are you doing with all these blueprints?

question: Some buildings I'm working on.
answer: Are you...an architect?

question: Well, just until I get my PGA Tour card.
answer: What's that?

question: I work with retards.
answer: I beg your pardon?

question: You know... ...the guys who ride the short bus.
answer: Isn't that a little politically incorrect?

question: The hell with that. No one's gonna tell me who I can and can't work with.
answer: No, I mean

question: --There's this one kid, we call him Mongo on account of he's a mongoloid. He got out of his cage once and--
answer: --He's in a cage?!

question: Well it's more of an enclosure really.
answer: They keep him confined? That's bullshit!

question: That's what I said, so I went out and got him a leash you know, one of those clothesline runners for the backyard. He's got plenty of room out there to dig. The kid's really blossomed. Now I can take him to ball games, movies--you know, happy stuff.
answer: That sounds like fun.

question: Yeah, it's fun for them, but it's heaven for me. Those goofy bastards are just about the best thing I have in this crazy old world. Ooh, hey, I gotta run.
answer: Look, uh, I was thinking maybe we should go have dinner sometime.

question: Hey, shit-for-brains, be careful not to scratch that thing, huh?
answer: What?

question: You heard me. You already put a fucking nick in my piano.
answer: I'll try to be more careful.

question: S'matter with you? You look like you're fading.
answer: The thing's kind of heavy.

question: Heavy? Heavy?! What I wouldn't give to know what heavy feels like, you insensitive prick.
answer: No, I just meant...

question: So...I see you made the news.
answer: It wasn't my truck--I was helping out a guy in a wheelchair.

question: Uh-huh. Where was he?
answer: Out getting coffee.

question: Yeah, that's more or less what the others said, too. Out getting coffee...supposed to meet him here...picking up my grandma...
answer: Bob, do you remember Mary?

question: Who?
answer: Mary.

question: From high school Mary? Yeah, I saw her about six months ago at a convention in Las Vegas.
answer: A convention? How'd you see her at a convention?

question: I'm an orthopedic surgeon, she's an orthopedic surgeon.
answer: Babe? Mary's a babe!

question: Babe? Mary's a babe!
answer: What?

question: My Mary--she's not in Japan, she's single, and she's got no rugrats. She does have a little gambling problem, she plays the football cards a bit too much, but she's a babe, a surgeon babe!
answer: Huh? But why did Healy?

question: Well think about it.
answer: No You mean...?

question: Uh-huh.
answer: The lazy fuck just didn't bother to look her up.

question: That sneaky prick was probably practicing his jai alai.
answer: Well then you've got to call her, man.

question: So who's the lucky guy?
answer: Name's Patrick, I met him at the driving range.

question: Good lookin'?
answer: He's no Steve Young.

question: What's he like?
answer: I don't know. He's kind of a mook.

question: What's a mook?
answer: You know, a mookalone, a schlep.

question: Then why you going out with him if he's a schlep?
answer: Come on, Magda

question: I don't watch the new ones.
answer: This one's almost thirty years old. It's about a young kid and an old lady who fall in love.

question: That's exactly why I don't watch 'em anymore--it's bullshit! Why the hell would an old lady go for a young kid?
answer: The point is, love isn't about money or social standing or age, it's about connecting with someone, having things in common kindred spirits.

question: You mean he doesn't like bad guys.
answer: 'That right?

question: He can tell you're an animal nut. You are, aren't ya?
answer: Truth is I usually get along better with animals than with people. In Nepal the villagers call me 'Kin-tan-tee', which means 'man who is loved by many animals... ...who love him a lot, too...and so on.'

question: Would you like a glass of tea or something?
answer: You got a brew?

question: Fine. Fine.
answer: Here you go. What's that smell?

question: The museum? I thought we were going out to dinner?
answer: We will, but first I have a surprise.

question: A surprise?
answer: The architecture exhibit! My friend Tucker is going to be here. He's an architect, too. You guys will have tons to talk about. I know he's around here someplace.

question: What say we get outta here and go crush a bucket?
answer: We just got here thirty seconds ago. Isn't this stuff great?

question: Deco.
answer: Would you call that a portico or a vestibule?

question: That...? Vestibule.
answer: How about--?

question: When you look at architecture, try not to concern yourself with the pieces--look at the building in its totalitarianism.
answer: Tucker!

question: Hey, no kidding? Where are your offices?
answer: Mainly I work out of Boston.

question: Boston, huh? Did you get your degree up there?
answer: Yes yes, I did get my degree up there.

question: Harvard?
answer: You bet.

question: Did you study under Kim Greene?
answer: Among others.

question: Kim and I are close friends!
answer: Well, I'll tell her I ran into you.

question: You mean him.
answer: Well...that's debatable.

question: Really? But he's been married for twenty years--they've got six kids.
answer: Nice smokescreen, isn't it?

question: Where would I have seen your work?
answer: Have you been to Let's see--Santiago, Chile?

question: Absolutely! I was there twice last year. Which building is yours?
answer: Do you know the...soccer stadium?

question: Did you build the Estadio Olympico?
answer: No...just down the street, the Amigo Tower.

question: I'm sorry, I'm not familiar with it. What style?
answer: Uh, sort of nouveau deco...with a big vestibule. Check it out next time you're up there.

question: You know, I really should take your card.
answer: Oh look, it's Doob! Will you excuse me a minute, Tucker? Dooby, you old sheep-fucker! How the hell are ya? Oh, sorry. Anyone ever tell you you look just like Jim Dubois?

question: Thanks for picking me up.
answer: No prob, I could use the company. I've been on the road going on fifteen hours straight.

question: I know how you feel--I been standing in the same spot for the last five hours. You know it's against the law to pick up a hitchhiker in this state.
answer: That must make it tough.

question: Sucks. So what's up? You some kind of salesman or something?
answer: Nah. I'm...I'm nothing.

question: Oh. Well I am.
answer: Hm?

question: A salesman--that's what I am. I mean, I'm gonna be anyway. I'm starting my own company--video sales--just as soon as I get enough seed money.
answer: 'That right? Good for you.

question: Yeah, you wouldn't believe my idea--it's a home run. You ever hear of Eight-Minute Abs?
answer: The exercise tape? Sure, I've seen it on

question: Two million copies it sold last year. Two million, man. But not next year--my idea's gonna blow them outta the water. Get this
answer: I see where you're going.

question: Think about it. You walk into a video store and you see Eight-Minute Abs and right next to it you see Seven-Minute Abs--which one you gonna spring for?
answer: I'd go with the seven.

question: Bingo. Especially since we guarantee you'll get every bit as good a work-out.
answer: How do you guarantee that?

question: Well it's the company motto
answer: Huh. That sounds great. Unless someone else comes out with Six-Minute Abs. What the--?

question: Huh. That sounds great. Unless someone else comes out with Six-Minute Abs. What the--?
answer: THIS IS A RAID!

question: Wait a second, it's not what you think. No! I was pissing!
answer: Yeah, I'll bet you all were. Come on, in the truck.

question: That grandmother of yours--she's really something.
answer: Magda? She's not my grandmother--actually she rents the apartment right next to mine. Her husband passed away a couple years ago so she doesn't like to be alone.

question: And it doesn't cramp your style?
answer: Sadly, no. Well except for the lint.

question: Lint?
answer: Yeah, I think it's that dog of hers running around on the rug all day--just makes for a lot of lint. Look at this...

question: You know, sometimes I wish I could be like Magda and not go home. I'd like to just bounce around for awhile, do a little traveling...
answer: Why bounce when you have your own condo in Nepal to go to?

question: Ah, I'd sell that. Start fresh in a new place, quit the architect game, slow things down, read more books, see more movies...
answer: You're a movie buff?

question: Try to be. It's tough going with the crap they make today. If Dumb and Dumber's the best they've got to offer I say thanks but no thanks.
answer: Have you seen it?

question: No. But the Boston Globe critic Jay Carr hated it.
answer: A fucking moron.

question: Huh. I guess I just wish they made them like they used to. You know, something like The Heartbreak Kid...or Harold and Maude.
answer: Harold and Maude is my all-time favorite movie.

question: Ouch. Come on, don't bust my chops. I know it's corny, but I do love it.
answer: Pat, I'm not kidding. I really think it's the greatest--

question: --Love story of our time.
answer: Yeah.

question: Wow. I thought I was the only one.
answer: So...

question: Yeah...I guess this is it, huh?
answer: I guess.

question: Well, I'll see ya.
answer: What?

question: No, forget it, it was stupid.
answer: Come on, what were you going to say?

question: Nah, really, it was moronic.
answer: Just say it.

question: Oh. The hitchhiker.
answer: So you admit it?

question: Guilty as charged. I'm not gonna play games with you. I could give you a song and dance but what's the point? I did it and we all know it. The hitcher himself told me it's illegal The irony.
answer: Well, uh, can you tell us his name?

question: Jeez, I didn't catch it.
answer: So he was a stranger? It was totally random?

question: He was the first hitcher I saw, what can I tell you? Now cut to the chase, how much trouble am I in?
answer: First tell us why you did it.

question: Mornin', Jane.
answer: What's up, Doc?

question: Tucker, you look different some how. Did you do something with your hair?
answer: The teeth, the teeth. I got 'em capped.

question: Oh yeah, they look great.
answer: You don't think they're too big?

question: No no, the bigger the better. But I must say, they could be a little brighter. Nothing's sexier than a mouthful of pearly whites.
answer: You ever been laid in this office?

question: Behave yourself, Tucker. Come on, what are you doing here?
answer: I wanted to talk to you about your friend Patrick.

question: He's a nice guy, isn't he?
answer: Well that's what I'm trying to figure out. How long have you known him?

question: Not long at all, but I really like him. Okay, I know he's a little different, Tucker, but that's what I like about him. He's a guy. A real guy. He dresses like a dork and eats corndogs and he isn't always politically correct and he probably farts, too. And that's okay with me.
answer: That's what you've been looking for--a farter?

question: Huh...that's strange.
answer: I thought so. Anyway, I hope you don't think I'm being meddlesome. I just think you should be careful with this guy.

question: No no no, Tucker, thank you.
answer: I mean let's face it, Mary, you're beautiful, you've got money, you trust people--I'm just saying, there's a lot of psychos out there.

question: You are one lucky sonofabitch, you know that?
answer: I am?

question: Didn't they tell you? That hitcher was just about to cut your throat when you stopped to take a leak. You got a fucking horseshoe up your ass, man.
answer: Yeah feels like it.

question: Flew. Told my wife I was going to a Promise Keepers convention.
answer: Shoot.

question: Remember our friend Healy? Well, I didn't know where to mail his last paycheck so I sent my assistant by his mother's apartment. Turns out there is no diabetic mom. Landlord said she's been dead for ten years.
answer: And this adversely affects me how...?

question: Don't you see?--Healy lied to us about everything! The landlord said when he got back from Miami he kept talking about falling for some doctor named Mary!
answer: Huh? What? No...My Mary? Mary wouldn't go for him....would she?

question: His address in Miami. You know, when you think about it, we really don't know the first thing about this guy.
answer: Jesus Christ what have I done?

question: Hey, watch your mouth--she's a great gal. I'm the dumbshit for lying to her.
answer: Why didn't you just tell her the truth?

question: I don't know. I guess...it just seems that women today are more impressed by the mighty buck than by some schmo who spent the last seventeen years scraping by on Peace Corp wages.
answer: But Jesus, Pat, if she's as special as you say, she's going to want to hear about the things you did.

question: Ahh.
answer: Come on, you could tell her about the irrigation ditches you dug in Sudan, the orphan babies who cried in your arms in Romania... ...the hope you gave Freddie the leper in Calcutta...

question: Look, I did all those things for myself. I'll be honest with you, I'm a selfish prick. I get a high from helping all of God's creatures. An honest to goodness high.
answer: That's bullshit, man you, uh, you were on the front line. Remember the, uh, malaria the, uh, typhoon fever that vicious strain of genital herpes?

question: Uh, sure. I cured a lot of nasty illnesses in third-world countries.
answer: Hey, love will make you do fucked-up things.

question: Well? What are you waiting for?
answer: I don't know what to say.

question: Tell her the truth about Healy! Blow the schmuck out of the water.
answer: Are you crazy? I've unleashed a psycho on her. She's gonna be fucking pissed. She's even more beautiful than I remember.

question: Get over there, you pussy! She's leaving!
answer: You asshole, what are you--

question: You asshole, what are you--
answer: Who's that?

question: It is you! It's me...Ted. From Rhode Island Ted.
answer: Oh my God...Ted. What are you...? I can't believe this. I haven't seen you since--

question: Yup, that's right. Junior prom...kinda.
answer: And did everything--?

question: I'm gonna take a rain check.
answer: I can't believe he remembered you. He never remembers anybody. You know I tried to call you for weeks after that.

question: Really? I never got a message.
answer: That's weird. I talked to your brother Jimmy five or six times.

question: He's dead.
answer: Oh, Ted I'm so sorry to hear that.

question: No, it was a good thing. I mean, good in that it was very quick.
answer: Oh. So...what brings you down here?

question: Funny story. You see, me and a buddy of mine decided to...ah...you know...just ...drive down.
answer: Well you look great. Are you married, do you have kids?

question: Nope, nope--dodged a few bullets. God, I cannot believe I'm standing here with Mary Jenson.
answer: Actually, it's Mary Brooks now.

question: Oh...are you...?
answer: Nope, haven't walked the plank yet. There was this guy back in college who was bothering me...got kind of ugly--a restraining order, the whole bit. Anyway, when I got out of Princeton I changed my name as a precaution.

question: Jeez...that sounds awful. Hey, what do you say we go out to dinner tonight, catch up on old times?
answer: Didn't we just do that?

question: Mary, we haven't seen each other in twelve years. Don't make me wait another day.
answer: Tell me where you're staying. I'll pick you up at eight.

question: Tell me where you're staying. I'll pick you up at eight.
answer: I'm buying bananas tonight.

question: Why?
answer: Back when I was your age I always used to make myself a big banana split after sex. I think you're gonna need one tonight.

question: Don't get ahead of yourself. You'll probably need it before I will.
answer: Don't bet on it. Last time I had a pap smear the guy needed leather gloves and an oyster shucker.

question: So maybe I could find a nice gentleman to take you to the movies.
answer: Knock it off, Pollyanna, just 'cause you're in love doesn't mean everyone else has to be.

question: Love? Come on, I wouldn't call it love.
answer: Oh no? I ain't seen you beaming like this since you broke ninety on the Blue Monster.

question: Well I am pretty psyched. I ran into a guy today I hadn't seen since high school.
answer: An old flame?

question: No, I'm not. I just want to get you-drunk so you'll pass out and I can have my way with Mary.
answer: Can I pour you one?

question: Thanks, but I've got to be going. Unfortunately, Doc, this isn't a social visit.
answer: What's up?

question: Well...I've got a little more news about your friend Healy.
answer: I know what you're going to say, but he already told me everything. I know he's not an architect. Tucker, I appreciate you doing all this, but I'm really strapped for time here and--

question: Mary, the man's a killer.
answer: What...?

question: I've got a friend in the Boston police department. He faxed me this this morning. I'll just give you the highlights. After a short stint as a petty thief, Patrick R. Healy graduated to armed robbery by the age of fourteen. At sixteen he committed his first murder--a pretty teacher's aid named Molly Pettygrove. He was incarcerated until age twenty-two when, despite a grim psychological profile, the state was forced to release him. In his mid-twenties and again in his early thirties he was suspected of homicides in the states of Utah and Washington. Unfortunately, the bodies were so badly decomposed that there wasn't enough evidence to hold him, and on and on and so forth and so on.
answer: Holy shit...

question: Holy shit...
answer: Puffy, get over here.

question: Magda!
answer: The little shit lied to me about that guy!

question: Oh God, I'm fucking nervous. I don't know if I'm ready for this, man.
answer: Just relax. Have you hit the cash machine?

question: Got cash.
answer: Car clean? Plenty of gas?

question: Check.
answer: Mints?

question: Copped a tin of Altoids at the car wash.
answer: Okay, sounds like you're all set. Just clean the pipes and it's a go.

question: Hm?
answer: You know, clean the pipes.

question: Pipes? What are you talking about?
answer: You jerk off before all big dates, right? Tell me you jerk off before your big dates.

question: No.
answer: Why's that?

question: I'm usually too tired to be.
answer: Wrong. It's because you ain't got the baby batter in your brain any more. That'll fuck with your head, that stuff will.

question: Huh.
answer: The most honest moment in a man's life is the five minutes after he's blown a load. That's a medical fact. And it's because you're no longer trying to get laid. You're actually thinking like a girl. They love that.

question: Jesus Christ you're right.
answer: You bet your ass I'm right. You don't go out with a loaded gun, you empty the barrels!

question: Holy shit, I've been going out with a loaded gun!
answer: People get hurt that way.

question: Hey.
answer: Hi, Ted.

question: You look great.
answer: Thanks.

question: Hm?
answer: On your ear, you've got something.

question: Sure.
answer: Oh great, I ran out.

question: Okay, Pat, take it easy--don't do anything stupid.
answer: Who the fuck do you think you are making up that bullshit about me?!

question: Whoa, whoa--I don't know what you're talking about.
answer: Maybe this'll jog your memory.

question: Okay, okay, I might've gotten some bad information.
answer: That stalker Ted got to you, right? You're working for him, aren't you, you little shit?

question: Who?
answer: This is your last chance, you fuck. Now either you come clean or I'm going to kick your ass from here to Tallahassee.

question: I LOVE HER, OKAY?!
answer: You what?

question: You heard me, goddamnit. I...I love her.
answer: What do you mean?

question: I mean I'm a fucking fraud. I'm no architect. Don't be a putz--who's been to Santiago twice in a year? Estadio Olimpico--please!
answer: But...but you knew people at Harvard.

question: I knew shit. The only thing I knew was that you were a fake and I made up everything else. My real name's Norm. I deliver pizzas.
answer: Bullshit!

question: Thanks, that's great.
answer: Thank you.

question: Now by killer, you mean...?
answer: I mean he murdered someone and did time back in Boston. The guy's a freak.

question: Jeez, Mary...I'm...
answer: Well, lucky for me I found out. Thank God I have friends like Tucker. Look, I'm sick of talking about stalkers. Let's talk about you.

question: ...So then in '94 I went back to Dade Community College for a semester and when the Wal-Mart cashier job fell through I hooked up with the Pizza Barn.
answer: And you met Mary how?

question: Just dumb luck. I delivered a pie to her one night and she answered the door in her nightgown--that was it for me. I went home that night, shaved my beard, and a week later I was laid out in her office with a broken back.
answer: How'd you manage that one?

question: Friend. Baseball bat.
answer: Nice.

question: Oh yeah, the plan was going along just fine until you showed up.
answer: Hey, hey, hey, I'm not the one who started telling bald-faced lies about the competition--that's crossing the line!

question: What line? The day you first laid your oily rap on my future wife you started a war!
answer: Future wife? Get real, man--you're nothing more than a glorified brother in her eyes.

question: Why you son of a--
answer: Okay, calm down, calm down--the bottom line is neither of us are going to get her if we don't do something about that headcase she's with now.

question: You hit the ball pretty good for a fourteen.
answer: No short game.

question: We should play some time...I mean, if you can afford to lose some money.
answer: What are you?

question: Twenty-two.
answer: Bullshit, a twenty-two doesn't carry a one-iron--don't sandbag me, lady.

question: Okay, sometimes I'm a nineteen.
answer: That's more like it. Two more nitrate-sicles please.

question: Nitrate-sicles--I like that.
answer: I say they should put more meats on a stick, you know? They got a lot of sweets on sticks--popsicles, fudgesicles, lollipops--but hardly any meat.

question: I agree there should be more.
answer: You know what I'd like to see? Meat in a cone. You could put corned beef hash in a cone, or chopped liver.

question: I like it. And think of the toppings--cheese, mushrooms, mint jelly
answer: Not to mention ketchup and hot peppers.

question: It's too bad you don't live down here, Ted.
answer: Yeah?

question: We've got a lot in common.
answer: Well...why don't you move back?

question: Ah, my roots here are too deep. I love my practice, the people I work with, Warren's got a nice thing going Why don't you just move down here and marry me? So you're a writer?
answer: Trying to be.

question: Well good for you. I bet it works out for you.
answer: We'll see. If it doesn't, what the hell, at least I gave it a shot.

question: That's right. And the good thing is you can do it anywhere.
answer: What about you, Mare? How the hell'd you manage to stay single?

question: ... and then it was all over.
answer: Wow. That's too bad. He sounds almost perfect.

question: Yeah...almost. You want to come up and watch Sportscenter?
answer: Uh no. I think I'm gonna get out while I'm ahead.

question: Ted...you're not that far ahead.
answer: Look, Mary, the truth is...I'll be in town for a while now but I don't think we should see each other for a few weeks.

question: Why not?
answer: Well...to be honest....I'm really crazy about you and it's making me nervous and when I get nervous I'm not myself and I'm afraid I'm going to doing something really dumb before we get started so I think I should just lay back until I regain my composure.

question: That's really sweet, Ted, but you should save it for one of your books.
answer: All right, let's go.

question: Magda, what are you doing?
answer: Oh, hi hon. Just straightening up.

question: Where's Puffy?
answer: Ah, he was being a pest so I put him in the bathroom.

question: Hey.
answer: Did you hire Pat Healy to follow me around?

question: What do you mean?
answer: It's not true...right, Ted?

question: Well, funny story there. You see, uh, it started out as a uh...yeah...it's true. =
answer: Get out.

question: Wait, hold on, Mary--it's not as bad as it sounds. I certainly didn't know--
answer: That you put a murderer on my trail?

question: Well yeah, I didn't know much about him. I just thought--
answer: What did you think, Ted? That you could spy on me and trick me into thinking you were someone I could...really go for?

question: Mary, I swear I wasn't trying to trick you.
answer: Then what the fuck did you do it for?

question: I did it because because I'd never stopped thinking about you and if I didn't find you I knew my life would never be good again.
answer: Please leave.

question: Mary, come on...
answer: Go!

question: Who the fuck are you?
answer: He's in love with Mary, too.

question: You fucked me, man? Why would you do that?
answer: What do you mean 'why'?

question: Look, you asked me to follow your girl around, and I did and I started to like her, and then I realized I just couldn't in good conscience do it.
answer: Do what?

question: Turn her over to a stalker.
answer: What?! You're calling me a stalker?

question: That's right--if you weren't you would've looked for her yourself!
answer: You're a sick man, you know that?

question: Yeah well fuck you! You just can't stand the fact that it was my turn.
answer: Your turn?

question: That's right, hot shot! My turn. What's the matter with me, huh? Why can't I ever get the great girl? Give the big pig with the B.O. to Healy, right? Well I was sick of it, man! No more--it was my turn. It was time for me...time for me...to be happy.
answer: Well you didn't have to blow us both out of the water. Jesus Christ, just because she found out about you, why'd you have to take me down with you?

question: I don't know what you're talking about.
answer: I'm talking about the letter, asshole.

question: What?
answer: Are you telling me you didn't send Mary a letter outlining our deal?

question: Why the fuck would I do that? I'd be screwing myself.
answer: What?

question: You fucking prick, we had a deal--you said you wouldn't fuck me and I wouldn't fuck you until we had this fuck out of the fucking picture. You crossed the line, man.
answer: Whoa, whoa, you're getting crazy now. Why would I cross the line--what do you think I got no pride?

question: Oh that makes a lot of sense. Why would I rat myself out?
answer: Like I'm going to try to figure out a guy who's idea of courting is blowing farts in the chick's face

question: You were following us?
answer: Don't flatter yourself--I was following her, I always do. How the hell you think I got rid of Mary's boyfriend Steve?

question: Woogie? What are what are you doing here?
answer: Did you get my letter, Mare? The one about Ted?

question: You sent that?
answer: Uh-huh. I was worried about you.

question: Well...thank you. But...you know you're not supposed to be within four hundred yards of me.
answer: That's what I want to tell ya. I've been through two years of extensive psychotherapy and you know what? You were right--I needed help.

question: That's great, Woogie, I'm happy you're better--you seem...good--but...you put me through quite an ordeal, you know.
answer: Look at me.

question: Woogie, I caught you red-handed.
answer: All right, I did, but I was in a weird place then.
